name: Level 30 Divine Weapon Master Build Request
author: The Hoff

posts.author: The Hoff
posts.content:
Looking to play a weapon master using a rapier/scimitar and shield that can take advantage of divine might/shield, divine favor, and greater magic weapon. I've been going back and forth between STR and CHA based paladins, swapping in and out fighter and champion of torm, and generally pulling my hair out. This is for Arelith, so we're capped at level 30 and it's a relatively low magic world. The first three levels of a new class have to be taken all together before switching to another class, and we can use gifts to boost three different stats by 2. The closest I've come to being happy with this idea is a human Paladin 15/Fighter 8/WM 7. If you want to get creative, there's a few custom classes that could be considered:
- Harper Paragon, a harper scout path that automatically grants divine grace, divine might, and divine shield across levels 1 through 5. Harper paragons add their full Harper level to arcane and divine spellcasting. All normal Harper features are lost except for the bonus feats.
- Harper Priest, another variant that adds +3 effective levels for Turn Undead at level 2. Harper priests add their full Harper level to divine spellcasting. I think there's some other minor bonuses but I can't check right now.
- Favoured Soul, a bard path that trades bard song for 0% arcane spell failure and an unlimited number of spells per day (spells have a cooldown after being cast related to their level).

I feel like I need divine favor, GMW, and taunt in order to have a competitive AB for PvP. And I guess I don't have to have divine might, but I just want to see a crap load of divine damage when my holy warrior hits. Is that so much to ask? Is cleric possible here? Should I go the great smiting route instead?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Welcome aboard the guild community, mate!  So glad you were able to find us

Whenever someone indicates a low-magic world, I immediately think caster class.  In this case, that would be a self-buffing cleric, however...

The question you need to ask yourself is: How bad do I desire the ability to smite and taunt?  If the answer to both these preferences is VERY DESIRABLE, then you are stuck with either Pally or BG. Clerics don't taunt.  Well, not very well anyway and certainly don't smite.

The main problem is that you will allocating to too many abilities at once:  STR 13 (for PA/DM/DS), DEX 13 (for Dodge/WM) CHA 13 (for DM/DS), INT 13 (for Expertise/WM) and WIS 14+ (minimum buffing) and without at least WIS 16-18, you will have fewer buff slots even as pally.  So you see how thin the spread will be just to enable WM in combo with DM/DS?

The one class that can compensate for a lowish primary attack ability is cleric. The key advantages over pally are Battletide +2 AB (+2 AC vs enemy attack) and Divine Power (full BAB attack) not to mention True Seeing, Magic Vest, Darkfire, Neg nrg Protect... etc... buffs that can make up for lack of enhancements on gear especially on low-magic PWs.

The only real trick I see designing a ftr/clc/wm is keeping pre-epic BAB no higher than 15 to exploit DP to its fullest.  But it's your choice.  You are the one that will be playing it and if there is a thematic reason for preference it could cost potential.

Save all those turn attempts for raising damage total.  Domains & skills allocated somewhat randomly without more intimate knowledge of what the server provides enhancement-wise.

Ummm... unless Arelith has changed alignments of vanilla base classes, there is no legal way to combo Pally with bard.  As for those other custom classes mentioned, I'll leave it to you to consider the possibilities since I have no clue how to design around them.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
The Hoff wrote:
Thanks Hip! I agree on letting go of divine shield; magic vestment x 2 and shield of faith more than make up for it. But I noticed you weren't able to fit in Improved Critical. I feel like that needs to be in a critical hit-oriented build. What about swapping out blind fight for knockdown, since clerics get ultravision and true seeing?

 
TS won't help vs. concealed.  Ultravision is only used to pierce magical darkness (avoid blindness).  Blind Fight should always be #1 on your list of melee feats unless you are guaranteed not to encounter any concealed types (like shadows or those buffed with ImpInvis or one of the Visages). Even PBS-users will appreciate the same feat when it comes to economizing on expensive ammo and dispatching those pesky touch attacks quickly.

Omitting IC was partly due to my own numbness and also prioritizing feat selection.  Obviously, 2 more levels of fighter pre-epic would have solved this but at the cost of the Clc 15 optimization of buffs (only clc 13/wm7/ftr 10 would be possible).  The proverbial rock and hard place for a 30-level cap build rears its ugly head.  The only other feat which is borderline expendable is Extend Spell but depending on rest opportunities, it could become more of a staple than a luxury.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I prefer this version myself Hoff,

Better hit points, better saves (once you boost your charisma), better attack bonus, immune to fear, better armour class (w/ divine shield), taunt and a more "clean" approach overall. It might not have the final potential of a cleric build but on the other hand, it doesn't need that much buffing anyway. A dispel coming your way won't leave you "naked" as with a cleric build. If you don't need "heal" in your skill list, i would take off a point from both dexterity and intelligence and boost constitution by the same amount. I don't see "extent spell" either, don't you like your DF's lasting 20 rounds? Perhaps drop KD for that, but leave BF in there definitely.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
It really comes down to whether your cleric play is adept or not, Hoff.  Fear threat is easy to negate with the intrinsic +12 will buffs against the rare 3 dragons that cannot be protected against with the alignment buff (always buff with both alignments).  IIRC, the only neutral dragons are mist, prismatic and wyverns... which cannot be smited or taunted (check out their ancient CON and concentration when you get a chance).  One extra minor +will piece of jewelry is enough to win the save against ancients' fear aura every roll, if you feel unlucky and need the insurance.   Vs undead, Protect vs. Evil is enough to neutralize all fear auras.

I've yet to fall to mobs of dispellers with any of my buffer clerics since I will always do my recon under Greater Sanctuary and then launch either HotG or WoF to control the dispel threat.  Too bad there's no room for Craft Wand because the HotG wand version is clvl 20, 5 higher than the level this toon will reach.

With True Seeing, you will be immune to most sneaks (and Crippling Strikes) unless you stand inside a shroud of darkness.  The main advantage is that you can wade into mobs of shadow drain without any concern that your strength will end up at 4 (touch attacks ignore AC btw).

But being comfortable with the cleric repertoire is important because you may not want to spend the time to master the divine arts while leveling a new toon.  It's easier to just keep clicking and swallowing potions I suppose.  It's too bad you can't exploit DP but that feat is really just icing on the cake of divine mastery, not essential.

Oh, while we are on the subject of divine spellcasting... I am curious.  Has Arelith nerfed Harm?  Many servers have, feeling it is unbalanced.

posts.author: The Hoff
posts.content:
HipRedux wrote:
Oh, while we are on the subject of divine spellcasting... I am curious.  Has Arelith nerfed Harm?  Many servers have, feeling it is unbalanced.
They changed both harm and heal, as described below. Taken from here: http://wiki.arelith.com/Spell_changes

Harm: Deals 10 points of damage per caster level.
Heal: Heals 100 + 5*CL. Capped at 200 at level 20.
